skos.definition: A hereditary disorder of type IV collagen causing progressive nephropathy, sensorineural hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities, typically resulting from mutations in COL4A3, COL4A4, or COL4A5 genes.
skos.scopeNote: Classic triad of nephritis, sensorineural deafness, and ocular abnormalities; X-linked most common

content.title: Alport Syndrome
content.summary: Alport syndrome is a hereditary nephropathy caused by mutations in type IV collagen genes (COL4A3, COL4A4, COL4A5), affecting the glomerular basement membrane, cochlea, and lens. It classically presents with microscopic hematuria progressing to proteinuria and ESKD, accompanied by sensorineural hearing loss and characteristic ocular findings.
key_points: Caused by mutations in COL4A3, COL4A4, or COL4A5 (type IV collagen genes)
X-linked dominant (COL4A5) is most common (80%); autosomal forms also exist
Classic triad: nephritis, sensorineural hearing loss, ocular abnormalities
Males with X-linked disease progress to ESKD by age 20-30
Electron microscopy shows basket-weave appearance of GBM
RAAS blockade slows progression but cannot prevent ESKD
content.statement: Alport syndrome represents a spectrum of hereditary basement membrane disorders caused by mutations in type IV collagen. Understanding the inheritance patterns, clinical manifestations, and natural history is essential for diagnosis, family counseling, and management planning.

explanation.intuition: Think of type IV collagen as the 'rebar' that reinforces basement membranes throughout the body. In Alport syndrome, this collagen is defective, causing the glomerular basement membrane to become thin and fragile, eventually leading to scarring and kidney failure. The same collagen is found in the inner ear and eye, explaining the hearing and vision problems.
explanation.key_insight: The GBM normally undergoes a 'developmental switch' from α1α2α1 collagen IV (fetal) to α3α4α5 collagen IV (mature). In Alport syndrome, this switch cannot occur due to mutant collagen, leaving an immature GBM that is mechanically weak and progressively damaged by normal filtration pressures.
explanation.technical_details: Type IV collagen α3, α4, and α5 chains form a triple-helical network in the mature GBM, cochlear basement membrane, and lens capsule. Mutations in COL4A3/A4 (chromosome 2) cause autosomal forms; mutations in COL4A5 (X chromosome) cause X-linked disease. The defective GBM shows characteristic ultrastructural changes: thickening, thinning, lamellation, and basket-weave appearance on EM.

definitions_glossary.type_IV_collagen: Network-forming collagen specific to basement membranes; composed of six different alpha chains (α1-α6)
definitions_glossary.glomerular_basement_membrane: GBM - specialized basement membrane between podocytes and endothelium; primary filtration barrier
definitions_glossary.COL4A5: Gene encoding collagen IV α5 chain; located on X chromosome; mutations cause X-linked Alport
definitions_glossary.COL4A3: Gene encoding collagen IV α3 chain; mutations cause autosomal recessive or dominant Alport
definitions_glossary.COL4A4: Gene encoding collagen IV α4 chain; mutations cause autosomal recessive or dominant Alport
definitions_glossary.basket_weave_appearance: Characteristic EM finding in Alport syndrome showing irregular GBM with lamellation and splitting
definitions_glossary.sensorineural_hearing_loss: Hearing loss due to inner ear (cochlear) dysfunction; bilateral and progressive in Alport syndrome
definitions_glossary.anterior_lenticonus: Conical protrusion of the anterior lens surface; pathognomonic for Alport syndrome
definitions_glossary.dot_and_fleck_retinopathy: Retinal findings in Alport syndrome; yellowish-white dots in perimacular region
definitions_glossary.thin_basement_membrane_disease: Benign familial hematuria; may be heterozygous carrier state for autosomal Alport
definitions_glossary.post_transplant_anti_GBM: Alloimmune response to normal collagen IV in transplanted kidney; rare complication
definitions_glossary.X_linked_dominant: Inheritance pattern where affected males are more severely affected than heterozygous females
definitions_glossary.developmental_switch: Normal replacement of α1α2α1 collagen IV with α3α4α5 network during kidney maturation
definitions_glossary.podocyte: Specialized epithelial cell wrapping glomerular capillaries; contributes to filtration barrier

pathophysiology.mechanism: Mutations in COL4A3, COL4A4, or COL4A5 prevent normal assembly of the α3α4α5 collagen IV network in the GBM. The persistence of immature α1α2α1 collagen leaves the GBM susceptible to mechanical stress, leading to progressive thinning, thickening, and lamellation. This causes hematuria, proteinuria, and eventually glomerulosclerosis.

inheritance_patterns.X_linked: 80% of cases; COL4A5 mutations; males severely affected (ESKD by 20-30), females variable (carrier state to mild disease)
inheritance_patterns.autosomal_recessive: 15% of cases; homozygous or compound heterozygous COL4A3/A4 mutations; both sexes equally affected
inheritance_patterns.autosomal_dominant: 5% of cases; heterozygous COL4A3/A4 mutations; milder phenotype, later-onset ESKD

extrarenal_pathology: Cochlea: same collagen network in basilar membrane causes high-frequency hearing loss
Eye: lens capsule and retina abnormalities from defective collagen IV

renal: Microscopic hematuria (earliest finding, often from childhood)
Episodes of gross hematuria (triggered by URI)
Chronic kidney disease progressing to ESKD
hearing: Present in 80% of X-linked males, variable in females
ocular: Usually does not affect vision significantly

clinical_criteria: Family history of hematuria ± renal failure

genetic_testing.advantages: Non-invasive, can identify carriers, enables genetic counseling

renal_biopsy.light_microscopy: Often nonspecific; may show FSGS pattern late
renal_biopsy.immunofluorescence: Absent α3, α4, α5 collagen IV staining (X-linked males); mosaic pattern in carrier females
renal_biopsy.electron_microscopy: Diagnostic: GBM thinning/thickening, lamellation, basket-weave appearance

renoprotection: ACE inhibitors or ARBs - first-line; shown to delay ESKD by 5-10 years
Start at diagnosis of proteinuria, even in children
SGLT2 inhibitors - emerging evidence for benefit
renal_replacement_therapy: Kidney transplantation is treatment of choice for ESKD
3-5% risk of post-transplant anti-GBM disease (Alport post-transplant nephritis)

prognosis.X_linked_males: ESKD by age 20-30 in most; hearing loss in 80%
prognosis.autosomal_recessive: ESKD by age 20-30, similar to X-linked males
prognosis.autosomal_dominant: Later onset; ESKD in 50% by age 60

learning_objectives: Describe the genetic basis and inheritance patterns of Alport syndrome
Recognize the classic clinical triad of nephritis, hearing loss, and ocular abnormalities
Interpret renal biopsy findings, particularly electron microscopy features
Differentiate Alport syndrome from thin basement membrane disease
Outline management strategies to slow progression to ESKD
Explain the risk of post-transplant anti-GBM disease
clinical_pearls: Family history of hematuria with hearing loss = think Alport syndrome
Anterior lenticonus is pathognomonic - always do ophthalmologic exam
Thin basement membrane disease may be a carrier state for autosomal Alport
Start ACE inhibitors early - proven to delay ESKD by years
Genetic testing is now preferred over skin/kidney biopsy for diagnosis
Warn transplant team about post-transplant anti-GBM risk (rare but serious)

common_question_stems: Young male with hematuria, proteinuria, and hearing loss
Family pedigree showing X-linked inheritance pattern with nephritis
Patient with Alport syndrome receiving kidney transplant
exam_tips: Alport = COL4A mutations + nephritis + hearing loss + eye findings
X-linked = males affected severely, females variably

teaching_cases.scenario: 14-year-old boy with persistent microscopic hematuria since age 5, now developing proteinuria. Mother has isolated hematuria. Maternal uncle on dialysis at age 28.
teaching_cases.key_findings: High-frequency hearing loss on audiometry, anterior lenticonus on slit-lamp. EM shows basket-weave GBM.
teaching_cases.management: Start ACE inhibitor, regular monitoring, genetic counseling for family
